Test Object
Click to select and then place a test object.

Test Object
Click to select and then place a test object.

Fennec Fox
Click to select and then place a fennec fox, a fox adapted for living in a desert environment.

Spectacled Bear
Click to select and then place a spectacled bear, an arboreal, herbivorous bear with distinct facial markings.

Scimitar Horned Oryx
Click to select and then place a scimitar horned oryx, a nomadic desert oryx.

American Bison
Click to select and then place an American bison, a large bovine that once roamed North America in great herds.

Florida Panther
Click to select and then place a Florida panther, an endangered subspecies of puma adapted to the wetlands.

Javan Rhinoceros
Click to select and then place a Javan rhinoceros, a reclusive, heavily armored rhinoceros.

Baird's Tapir
Click to select and then place a Baird's Tapir, an endangered ungulate from Central America.

Barren-Ground Caribou
Click to select and then place a barren-ground caribou, also known as a reindeer.

Giant Sable Antelope
Click to select and then place a giant sable antelope, a large, aggressive antelope.

Wolverine
Click to select and then place a wolverine, a small mustelid with enthusiastic eating habits.

Koala
Click to select and then place a koala, the best known Australian animal.

Gray Wolf
Click to select and then place a gray wolf, also known as a timber wolf.

Bornean Orangutan
Click to select and then place a Bornean orangutan, an endangered primate from Southeast Asia.

African Wild Dog
Click to select and then place an African wild dog, easily recognized by its vivid markings.

Northern White-Cheeked Gibbon
Click to select and then place a northern white-cheeked gibbon, an endangered primate from Asia.

Przewalski's Wild Horse
Click to select and then place a Przewalski's wild horse, an endangered horse from central Asia.

Komodo Dragon
Click to select and then place a Komodo dragon, the largest living lizard.

Markhor
Click to select and then place a markhor, a nimble-footed alpine animal.

Spanish Lynx
Click to select and then place a Spanish lynx, a critically endangered big cat.

Galapagos Giant Tortoise
Click to select and then place a Galapagos giant tortoise, an endangered tortoise from the remote Galapagos islands.

Galapagos Giant Tortoise Egg
Click to select and then place a Galapagos giant tortoise egg.

Alpine Sea Holly
Click to select and then place alpine sea holly, a beautiful but endangered blue flower.

Himalayan Oak
Click to select and then place a Himalayan oak, a large hardy tree.

Giant Sequoia
Click to select and then place a giant sequoia, the most massive living thing on earth.

Joshua Tree
Click to select and then place a Joshua tree, a spiny yucca tree native to western North America.

Pink Lady's Slipper
Click to select and then place pink lady's slipper, an orchid found in temperate climates.

Puya Plant
Click to select and then place a puya plant, a native of South America and a favorite of spectacled bears.

Bur Oak
Click to select and then place a bur oak, a common prairie tree.

Feathertop Wiregrass
Click to select and then place feathertop wiregrass, a common Australian grass.

Golden Barrel Cactus
Click to select and then place a golden barrel cactus, which is endangered in the wild due to collectors.

Red Oat Grass
Click to select and then place red oat grass, a common savannah grass in Africa and Australia.

Shepherd's Tree
Click to select and then place a shepherd's tree, a common sight in Africa.

Yellow Ipe Tree
Click to select and then place a yellow ipe tree, a typical tree of the South American cerrado.

Lady Fern
Click to select and then place a lady fern, a common sight in temperate forests.

Big Bluestem
Click to select and then place big bluestem, a prairie grass that can grow up to 10 feet tall.

Prickly Pear Cactus
Click to select and then place a prickly pear cactus, one of the Galapagos giant tortoise's favorite foods.

Scythian Lamb
Click to select and then place a Scythian lamb, an endangered tree fern used in traditional Asian medicine.

Durian Tree
Click to select and then place a durian tree, which produces a delicious but pungent fruit.

Lingonberry
Click to select and then place lingonberry, a member of the cranberry family.

Green Pitcher Plant
Click to select and then place a green pitcher plant, an endangered carnivorous plant that traps insects.

Labrador Tea
Click to select and then place Labrador tea, a common bush.

Sydney Blue Gum
Click to select and then place Sydney blue gum, a species of eucalyptus tree.

Perepat Tree
Click to select and then place a Perepat tree, a type of mangrove.
the elevated food dish with eucalyptus

Elevated Food Dish with Eucalyptus
Click to select and then place the elevated food dish containing eucalyptus leaves, the koala's favorite food.
the elevated food dish with berries

Elevated Food Dish with Berries
Click to select and then place the elevated food dish with berries, which enables tall animals to reach their food more easily.

Hollow Log with Berries
Click to select and then place the hollow log with berries. Many animals instinctively forage for food in hollow logs.

Food Dish with Eucalyptus
Click to select and then place the food dish with eucalyptus leaves. Since they're small, food dishes needed to be refilled often.

Food Dish with Berries
Click to select and then place the food dish with berries. Since they're small, food dishes needed to be refilled often.

Eucalyptus
Click to select and then place eucalyptus leaves, the koala's favorite food.

Berries
Click to select and then place berries, a tasty fruit treat for woodland creatures.

Substrate Pile with Berries
Click to select and then place substrate (a pile of earth and other organic materials) mixed with berries.

Elephant Enrichment Log
Click to select and then place an elephant enrichment log, which elephants love to lift.

Salt Lick
Click to select and then place a salt lick, which all ungulates enjoy.

Feeder Ball
Click to select and then place a feeder ball, which primates love to play with and eat from.

Durian
Click to select and then place a durian, a spiny, pungent fruit beloved by orangutans.

Tire Swing
Click to select and then place a tire swing, which primates love to play on.

Cat Climber
Click to select and then place a cat climber, which big cats rest on, climb, and scratch.

Boreal Small Burrow
Click to select and then place a boreal-themed small burrow, used by animals such as the wolverine.

Boreal Large Burrow
Click to select and then place a boreal-themed large burrow, used by animals such as the gray wolf.

Desert Small Burrow
Click to select and then place a desert-themed small burrow, used by animals such as the fennec fox.

Desert Large Burrow
Click to select and then place a desert-themed large burrow, used by animals such as the fennec fox.

Scrub Small Burrow
Click to select and then place a scrub-themed small burrow, used by animals such as the Komodo dragon.

Scrub Large Burrow
Click to select and then place a scrub-themed large burrow, used by animals such as the Komodo dragon.

Small Restroom
Click to select and then place the small restroom, which can accommodate one guest at a time.

Family Restroom
Click to select and then place the family restroom. They cost more than small restrooms, but accommodate six more guests.

Hamburger Food Stand
Click to select and then place the hamburger food stand. Hamburgers are reasonably priced and reasonably filling.

Hot Dog Food Stand
Click to select and then place the hot dog food stand. Especially popular with kids, hot dogs are a classic American food.

Salad Food Stand
Click to select and then place the salad food stand. Kids usually don't like salads, but adults love them.

Soda Drink Stand
Click to select and then place the soda drink stand. Sodas are the most popular drink among zoo guests.

Sub Food Stand
Click to select and then place the sub food stand. Subs are meat-filled sandwiches that are commonly devoured for lunch.

Sushi Food Stand
Click to select and then place the sushi food stand. An expensive food choice, sushi is more popular with adults than kids.

Water Drink Stand
Click to select and then place the water drink stand. Water will satisfy your guests' most basic thirst needs.

Shish Kebab Food Stand
Click to select and then place the shish kebab food stand, which offers protein-rich food at a reasonable price.

Coffee Drink Stand
Click to select and then place the coffee drink stand. Adult guests love the caffeine jolt, and some younger guests are willing to try it too.

Cheesecake Cart
Click to select and then place the cheesecake cart. Adult guests love cheesecake for dessert.

Popcorn Cart
Click to select and then place the popcorn cart. Popcorn is a filling snack that may make your guests thirsty.

Pretzel Cart
Click to select and then place the pretzel cart. Pretzels may make guests thirsty.

Cotton Candy Cart
Click to select and then place the cotton candy cart. Cotton candy is a classic kids' treat.

Fruit Cup Cart
Click to select and then place the fruit cup cart. Many guests enjoy fruit as a healthy snack alternative.

Ice Cream Cart
Click to select and then place the ice cream cart, a favorite with young zoo guests.

Discovery Kiosk
Click to select and then place a discovery kiosk, which increases educational donations.

Tropical Bounce House
Click to select and then place a tropical bounce house, which children love to play in.

Conservation Breeding Center
Click to select and then place a conservation breeding center, which helps you breed endangered species.

Face Painting Kiosk
Click to select and then place a face painting kiosk, where children can get their faces painted.

Headset Kiosk
Click to select and then place a headset kiosk, which provides wireless headsets to your guests.

Photo Kiosk
Click to select and then place a photo kiosk, where guests can admire your zoo photos.

Spectacled Bear Statue
Click to select and then place a spectacled bear statue, a magnificent sculpture of the South American animal.

Endangered Species Trash Can
Click to select and then place a trash can with an endangered species theme. Trash cans should be placed all over your zoo so that guests can dispose of their garbage.

Endangered Species Arch
Click to select and then place an arch with an endangered species theme. Arches are an attractive addition to paths or entrances to themed areas in your zoo.

Endangered Species Bench
Click to select and then place a bench with an endangered species theme. Guests enjoy visiting themed areas in your zoo.

Endangered Species Lamp
Click to select and then place a lamp post with an endangered species theme. Guests enjoy visiting themed areas in your zoo.

Endangered Donation Box
Click to select and then place a donation box with an endangered species theme. Guests won't donate money if they can't find a donation box, so place them all over your zoo.

Endangered Umbrella Table
Click to select and then place an umbrella table with an endangered species theme. Umbrella tables provide guests with a shaded place to rest and eat.

Endangered Species Fountain
Click to select and then place a fountain with an endangered species theme. Guests appreciate the beauty of a well-placed fountain.

Endangered Viewing Canopy
Click to select and then place a viewing canopy with an endangered species theme. Viewing canopies allow guests to view animals in shaded comfort.

Endangered Music Rock
Click to select and then place a music rock with an endangered species theme, which plays music from speakers hidden inside.

Rock Pool
Click to select and then place a rock pool, which your guests enjoy seeing while on a tour.

Geyser
Click to select and then place a geyser, which your guest enjoy seeing while on a tour.

Balloon Bouquet
Click to select and then place a balloon bouquet, a colorful reminder of your baby animal arrival.

Bat Cave
Click to select and then place a bat cave, which your guests enjoy seeing while on a tour.

Volcano
Click to select and then place a volcano, which your guests enjoy seeing while on a tour.

Fog Machine
Click to select and then place a fog machine, which your guests enjoy while on a tour.

Mineral Deposit
Click to select and then place a mineral deposit, which your guests enjoy seeing while on a tour.

Snow Machine
Click to select and then place a snow machine, which your guests enjoy while on a tour.

Sky Tower
Click to select and then place a sky tower, which provides spectacular views of your zoo.

Crystal Tunnel
Click to select and then place a crystal tunnel, which your guests enjoy while on a tour.

Sequoia Tunnel
Click to select and then place a sequoia tunnel, which your guests enjoy while on a tour.

Zoo Attendance Statue
Click to select and then place a zoo attendance statue, awarded in recognition of your zoo's outstanding popularity.

Animal Babies Statue
Click to select and then place an animal babies statue, awarded in recognition of your efforts to breed endangered animals.

Endangered Species Fence
Click to select and then place sections of fence with an endangered species theme, a sturdy fence decorated with attractive mosaics.

Low Endangered Species Fence
Click to select and then place sections of low fence with an endangered species theme, a sturdy fence decorated with attractive mosaics.

Endangered Window Fence
Click to select and then place sections of window fence with an endangered species theme. Guests enjoy visiting themed areas in your zoo.

Conservation Fence
Click to select and then place sections of conservation fence, a fence designed to enclose conservation areas.

Low Conservation Fence
Click to select and then place sections of conservation fence, a fence designed to enclose conservation areas.

Wrought Iron Fence
Click to select and then place sections of wrought iron fence, a fence that is decorative, strong and doesn't block the guests' view.

Low Wrought Iron Fence
Click to select and then place sections of low wrought iron fence, a fence that is both decorative and strong.

Vehicle Gate
Click to select and then place a vehicle gate, which allows Jeep® vehicles to enter and exit animal exhibits.

Decorated Vehicle Gate
Click to select and then place a decorated vehicle gate, which allows Jeep® vehicles to enter and exit animal exhibits.
